prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: The Young Cluster Serpens South: the Kinematics of Cluster Formation

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Mosaic Area and Angular Resolution Requirement: We will image a 120'' x 80'' field of Serpens South with 2.5'' angular resolution. The mosaic will be made of 88 Nyquist sampled pointings, as seen in Figure 3 in the science justification. The filaments have a typical width of 15'', so we request a 2.5'' beam to produce 6 or more synthesized beams across them to identify substructure. To observe spatial scales as large as the typical filament width, we require the ACA. Our team has extensive experience with full image reconstruction with the CARMA array, so we have significant expertise in this technical area.
Correlator Setup and Velocity Resolution Requirement: The correlator setup will have a data rate of ~16MB/s. This is due to the number of molecular lines and spectral resolution needed to properly analyze the kinematics and chemistry of the filaments. N2H+ (J = 3 - 2) is the best molecule for exploring the coldest dense gas in the filaments and will be placed in the first baseband. We request 0.07 km/s velocity resolution; this request is based on the linewidths from our CARMA N2H+ (J= 1 - 0) spectra, which reveal FWHM ranging from ~0.2 - 2 km/s. Knowing this, 0.07 km/s velocity resolution will ensure at least 3 channels across the narrowest expected lines. We will bin channels to improve our sensitivity towards regions with wider lines. We will observe the H2CO (4_0,4 - 3_0,3) line in a second baseband; this molecule should be abundant in warm, dense gas where the abundant CO is suppressing the N2H+ abundance. We will observe DCO+ (J = 4 - 3) in a third baseband, providing the opportunity to examine the deuteration of the cold gas. None of these lines can be observed in the same baseband. With no extra time required, we will be able to observe the C34S (6 - 5) transition, which falls in the same baseband as H2CO, and DCN (J = 4 - 3), which falls in the same band as DCO+. Due to the isotopic sulfur, this transition will likely be optically thin in even the highest column density regions of dense gas. We will use the fourth baseband to observe the continuum emission at 1 mm.
Sensitivity Requirement and Time Request: We expect peak N2H+ J=3-2 line temperatures of 0.5-3 K across the filaments and central cluster region based on our CARMA maps, which detect J=1-0 line temperatures in the range of 3-12 K. We therefore request 0.16 K rms per channel (equivalent to 65 mJy rms within the requested 2.5'' beam) to achieve an expected SNR of ~3-20 across our mosaic. Our 88 pointing mosaic will require 3.1 hours of 12-m array time to achieve this sensitivity goal. There is an additional need for 12.4 hours of ACA time to recover the larger scale emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The CARMA Large Area Star-formation Survey of the Serpens South molecular cloud reveals a correlation between the dense molecular gas and the Hershel dust filaments. However, the CLASSy results raise many questions about the nature of the filaments and their interaction with the young cluster of protostars lying at the filament junction, which dominate the large-scale molecular distribution of the cloud. ALMA can provide crucial tests of core and filament formation scenarios by providing gas kinematics and morphology that can be achieved through observations of molecular lines that trace the density structure within the dense gas. We propose ALMA mosaic observations of N2H+ (3-2), H2CO (4_0,4-3_0,3), DCO+ (4-3), DCN (4-3), and dust continuum of a 120"×80" field in the southern portion of the hub where several filaments join. These observations will nail-down the role that filaments and filament junctions play in star formation by: providing the most detailed view of substructure in the filaments and condensing cores to date, leveraging multiple molecular species to trace gas in different chemical states, and achieving spatial resolution of 6 or more beams across the filaments.
